text.p: Finnish telephone equipment company Nokia Group rose in New York on Tuesday, its American Depositary Receipts (ADRs) boosted by strong earnings.
The ADR group rose overall along with the rest of Wall Street, helped by a falling yield on the U.S. Treasury 30-year bond that eased interest rate worries.
Advancers led decliners 334 to 132 at midday among 806 ADRs. The ADR group was up 0.76 percent and volume was 45 million shares at midday.
Nokia rose 4-7/8 to 62-5/8 after it reported a first quarter profit increase of 260 percent, above analysts' consensus estimate. The share was among the most active on the Nasdaq exchange.
Nokia also pulled Swedish telephone equipment company Telefon AB L.M. Ericsson higher. Ericsson rose 11/16 to 31-1/2, recovering further from a slump after reporting first quarter earnings Friday.

Irish software company Saville Systems Plc rose 3-1/2 to 39-1/2 after it reported first quarter earnings per share of $0.23 against $0.11 for the same period last year. The ADRs were among the most heavily traded on Wall Street.
British drug company Glaxo Wellcome Plc rose 1-1/4 to 38-3/4. The company was boosted as Goldman Sachs raised its price target for the company ahead of a briefing on research prospects.
Among Latin American ADRs, Mexican media company Grupo Televisa rose 1/8 to 22-7/8 and Brazilian telephone company Telebras rose one to 112-1/4.
